commit.message:
Merge pull request #22 from EdwardBetts/master

correct spelling mistake
correct spelling mistakes

Reverting no-TTY logic.

Colors enabled by default always, like it was before v2.0.0. Lead to
colorclass "not working" during testing in other libraries, leading to
confusion. Better to leave TTY detection up to developers.

Added disable_if_no_tty() convenience method.

Fixed printing box drawing chars on py26 Windows.

On Python 2.6 on Windows, trying to write box drawing characters using
sys.stdout.write (or err) raised UnicodeEncodeError. Apparently using
print() instead works fine.

Renamed image files.

Renamed subimage files and destination screenshot file names. For next
commit (more subimages and screenshots).

Removing PYTHONIOENCODING. Don't seem to need it anymore.

Supporting Python 2.6 x64 on Windows.

Looks like I need to define return and arg types for GetExitCodeProcess
in order to avoid [Error 6] The handle is invalid.

Python 2.6 in AppVeyor, assert in screenshot.py.

Adding Python 2.6 to AppVeyor tox tests. 32-bit only.

Refactored screenshot_until_match() in screenshot.py to have
AssertionError raised in there instead of asserting funciton output's
boolean value. Got some weird re-evaluation error locally.

Doing the same with ctypes.WinError() to get better Windows error
descriptions.

Also refactoring screenshot test to have assert in the function so I can
see count_found upon AssertionError.

Bumping up subimage dimension limit from 128x128 to 256x256 for other
tests. No need to be so strict.

Fixed README note with deprecated replace_streams.

Forgot to remove this last time.

Bumping version and updating changelog.

Preparing for release.

Revert is_enabled().

Reverting to current release code. No longer need "both" keyword arg.

Support native ANSI colors on latest Windows 10.

Windows 10 Insider since around February 2016 finally introduced support
for ANSI colors. No need to replace stdout and stderr streams to
intercept colors and issue multiple SetConsoleTextAttribute() calls for
these consoles.

Revert init_kernel32(). Added get_bg_color().

Changing my mind on impending native ANSI support on Windows. Making
init_kernel32() less compliated.

User may pipe stderr to file but not stdout, so we need to check both
streams for background color instead of just one. Added get_bg_color()
for this.

Tests: from colorclass import windows

Not importing individual variables/funcitons/classes in windows module
tests. Import statement was getting pretty big.

Refactored Windows class again.

Very low likelihood that Windows.enable() will be called (or need to be
called) a second time. And loading multiple kernel32 instances doesn't
really take up much memory. No longer recovering existing objects from
stderr/out.

Streamlined logic. If valid_handle is None, skipping everything since
every API call will fail. If True, then it's guaranteed that either
stdout or stderr can be replaced. If not replacing streams no need to
schedule atexit funciton.

Split up Windows class tests. Easier to follow and modify.

init_kernel32 with valid_handle.

Having init_kernel32() set handles to INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE if they are
already replaced (GetStdHandle returns that value if there is no
handle/piped to something).

Also having init_kernel32() find a valid handle or setting it to None to
signal no handles can be replaced. Future commits will use that value.

Enabling some tests on Linux/OSX.

Some tests don't necessarily only run on Windows. Enabling them on other
platforms for easier testing (I don't dev on Windows).

Using proper invalid handle mock value instead of 0 which technically
can be valid.

Don't parse results of previous operations.

Extension of https://github.com/Robpol86/colorclass/issues/16. Better to
do this for Color() % str() and other operations.

Prevent .format() from parsing non-Color strings.

When passing a non-Color string into .format(), it should not be parsed
by it. Only Color() instantiations should do parsing, not .format()
input values.

Fixes https://github.com/Robpol86/colorclass/issues/16

Added `keep_tags` kwkarg to Color class.

For https://github.com/Robpol86/colorclass/issues/16. Option to disable
parsing of curly brackets, leaving them as-is.

Test coverage. Testing enable/disable/enable.

Making sure enabling colors on windows, disabling, and enabling again
works fine. Using screenshots again for this.

Better Windows tests. Added replace_streams arg.

Latest Windows 10 console supports ANSI color codes natively. Adding
options to skip replacing stdout/stderr streams since it's not needed in
this version of Windows. Up to developer to determine that.

Wrote real tests for windows.py instead of the half-assed ones I wrote
long ago.

Testing WindowsStream.

Adding more tests. Removed non-executable code. No need to setattr since
__getattr__() handles original_stream passthrough.

Testing init_kernel32() and get_console_info().

Using ctypes.WinError() instead of raising IOError. The former gets the
actual error info from a Win32 API (GetLastError()) and raises
WindowsError (OSError subclass) with the information.

Fixed intermittent screenshot test failures.

Seems like there's an edge case with win32 APIs where CREATE_NEW_CONSOLE
doesn't maximize the window fast enough. The bug was if Windows was too
slow to maximize, the crop dimensions would be in the wrong position and
"Red" would not be in frame, thereby causing 0 subimage matches and
false negatives. Fixed bug by yielding current window size and position
every time the generator is iterated. Every time there are 0 matches the
while loop gets the latest size/position and tries again, instead of
using the previous coordinates.

Renamed new_max_window to just maximize. Always a new window, this bool
just toggled SW_MAXIMIZE.

Moving handles to close into __del__() and _handles.

Avoiding usless "res" variable allocation. Just assert.

Converted run_new_console() into class.

Splitting up context function into a context class. Seperates out large
function into three methods, easier to follow what's going on. Allows
inside of with block access to iterate returned object to get real-time
size/position of window instead of just a one time thing.

Increasing timeouts due to AppVeyor slowness.

Refactored windows.py.

Made module easier to understand. Converted WindowsCSBI into a couple of
functions. Moved structs out into the module scope.

Closing handles as per win32 documentation at the end of
run_new_console().

Windows screenshot testing with white console bg.

Testing light background auto colors on Windows. Using
STARTF_USEFILLATTRIBUTE and dwFillAttribute to invert the default colors
in a new console window.

Increased screenshot/example timeouts. Itermittent failure on Win 10.

Handling CreateProcess myself. Cropped screenshot.

Subprocess only partially implements STARTUPINFO(). It seems to ignore
lpTitle and dwFillAttribute. Implementing my own wrapper for it.

On Windows XP and Server 2012, cmd.exe does not fully maximize the
entire window. It only vertically maximizes. This may lead to false
positives on matching subimages on the screen. Mitigating this by doing
cropped screenshots with the help of GetWindowRect().

Moved varibles to windows.py. Fixed py26 tests.

Moved windows.py class variables into module variables. Easier to
follow.

Fixed Python 2.6 tests on Windows. Unicode character in a Pillow
author's name broke pip. Switching to easy_install. Requires WINDOR and
PYTHON_EGG_CACHE.

Testing Windows with screen shots.

Testing Windows support and checking if colors are actually working by
taking a screen shot and searching for the red colored "Red" sub image.

Since colors on Windows are created using API calls, I can't just verify
the output of a program like I do on OSX/Linux. Colors will always be
stripped. The only way I can think of to verfify colors actually work is
by taking a screen shot and scanning it for sub images.

Enabling the desktop on AppVeyor in order to let new console windows
appear on its desktop so screen shots may be taken.

Adding a --wait argument to example.py to give window animations time to
fully display the new console window and leave it open long enough for a
screen shot to be captured and processed.

Using Pillow to handle taking screen shots and reading BMP sub image
files.
